paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted genetic variant information for KCNH2, including penetrance data from a family case study of Long QT Syndrome.

individual_records.evidence_sentence: The proband (II-1 in Figure 1A; Table 1) had syncope at 10 and 11 years of age, but cardiac evaluation showed no apparent anomalies.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Long QTc (530 ms) after syncope episode.
individual_records.evidence_sentence: At age nine years he suffered an episode of syncope. After this episode, a complete cardiac evaluation revealed a long QTc (530 ms).

individual_records.phenotype_details: QTc of ~470 ms, experienced extreme bradycardia with sinus pauses followed by syncope.
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Although asymptomatic, the other brother (II-3 in Figure 1A; Table 1) was screened because of the family history of LQTS and was found to have a QTc of ~470 ms at age six years.

individual_records.phenotype_details: QTc values at the upper limit of normal (QTc: 440 ms)
individual_records.evidence_sentence: the father’s QTc values were at the upper limit of normal (QTc: 440 ms)

individual_records.phenotype_details: QTc values at the upper limit of borderline prolongation (QTc 471 ms)
individual_records.evidence_sentence: the mother’s were at the upper limit of borderline prolongation (QTc 471 ms)

functional_data.summary: KCNH2-p.C108Y is a non-functional channel with dominant-negative effects.

variants.segregation_data: No variant clearly segregated with the disease.
variants.population_frequency: Not reported in the ExAC database.
variants.evidence_level: Moderate evidence based on functional studies.
variants.additional_notes: KCNH2-p.C108Y is considered a novel variant.
key_quotes: Heterologous expression studies demonstrated that KCNH2-p.C108Y is a non-functional channel.
These results indicate that KCNH2-p.C108Y confers a loss-of-function with dominant-negative features consistent with a pathogenic mutation causing autosomal dominant LQTS.

functional_data.summary: KCNH2-p.K897T is a common variant that may act as a modifier.

variants.evidence_level: Low evidence based on population frequency.
variants.additional_notes: KCNH2-p.K897T was previously reported to influence the electrical activity of cardiac cells.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data for KCNH2 variants were extracted successfully.
